items.name: Causal Inference for the Brave and True
items.description: The best free intro to causal inference. DiD, IV, RDD, synthetic control — all with Python code you can run. No fluff.

items.name: The Effect
items.description: DAGs that don't suck. Nick HK explains causality like he's at a whiteboard, not a lectern. Free, modern, and actually enjoyable to read.

items.name: Causal Inference: The Mixtape
items.description: Scott Cunningham's guide — reads like a conversation, not a textbook. Code in Stata, R, and Python.

items.name: CausalML (Uber) Documentation
items.description: Synthetic data tutorials that feel like a game. Generate fake users, apply treatment, challenge yourself to recover the effect using Random Forest.

items.name: EconML Documentation
items.description: Microsoft's library for ML-based causal inference. Tutorials on heterogeneous treatment effects, double ML, and more.

items.name: DoWhy Library
items.description: Microsoft's causal inference library. Great for understanding causal graphs and robustness checks.

items.name: Causal ML Book (Chernozhukov et al.)
items.description: Applied Causal Inference Powered by ML and AI. Double/debiased ML, heterogeneous effects, and modern methods from the pioneers.

items.name: DoWhy User Guide
items.description: Microsoft's causal inference library. Graph-based causal inference, discovery algorithms, and Python implementations. Free official docs.

items.name: PyMC Labs Blog
items.description: Bayesian causal inference done right. MCMC, probabilistic programming, and causal models from the PyMC team.

items.name: CausalPy
items.description: Synthetic controls that feel like scikit-learn. Built on PyMC, perfect for quasi-experiments when you can't randomize.

items.name: Andrew Gelman's Blog
items.description: Stats, causal inference, experiment pitfalls. Frank, often funny, always insightful. The most-read stats blog for good reason.

items.name: Applied Econometrics Notes (Lal)
items.description: Applied econometrics notes and code by Apoorva Lal covering modern causal inference methods.

items.name: A Practitioner's Guide to DiD
items.description: Jonathan Roth et al.'s comprehensive guide to modern difference-in-differences. Staggered timing, pre-trends, and new estimators.

items.name: Causal RL Bridges
items.description: Educational resource on the synergies between causal inference and reinforcement learning. Includes code examples for optimal control using causal agents.

items.name: Eppo's Experimentation Guides
items.description: Practical guides on experiment design, stats engines, CUPED, and common pitfalls. Written by practitioners.

items.name: A/B Testing on Social Networks
items.description: Simulates a social graph in Python to prove why network effects ruin experiments, then shows cluster-based fixes.

items.name: DoorDash: Switchback Tests
items.description: Why treating one user affects another in marketplaces. Clear diagrams explaining interference as a living organism, not a static dataset.

items.name: Understanding Switchback Experiments (2024)
items.description: A modern take on SUTVA violations. Why you randomize time, not users, in marketplaces. The 30-minute window trick explained.

items.name: Uber: Making Experiment Evaluation 100x Faster
items.description: When your p-value calculation has billions of rows. The engineering reality of running causal inference at Uber scale.

items.name: Nextmv: Switchback Testing
items.description: Documentation that reads like a tutorial. Exact logic to split time into windows and washout periods for network A/B tests in Python.

items.name: Matteo Courthoud: Understanding CUPED
items.description: The closest author to Matheus Facure. Explains CUPED not as statistical theorem, but as simple linear regression adjustment in 3 lines of pandas.

items.name: Bytepawn: CUPED in Python
items.description: Short, punchy script simulating 1,000 experiments to prove variance actually goes down. Very satisfying to run.

items.name: Statsig Resources
items.description: Deep dives on sequential testing, variance reduction, and experiment analysis. Free stats engine docs.

items.name: Evan Miller's A/B Testing Tools
items.description: Sample size calculators, stats explainers, and practical A/B testing guides. Bookmark-worthy tools.

items.name: Evan Miller: How Not To Run an A/B Test
items.description: The article that taught the industry why peeking at p-values is a sin. Short, lethal, career-saving.

items.name: QuantEcon Lectures
items.description: High-quality computational economics in Python and Julia. Dynamic programming, time series, asset pricing — all with code.

items.name: Coding for practitioners
items.description: Arthur Turrell's practical guide. Python basics through advanced workflows — built specifically for econ researchers.

items.name: The Missing Semester (MIT)
items.description: Command line, Git, debugging, shell scripting. The CS skills they don't teach in econ PhD programs but you absolutely need.

items.name: Beyond Jupyter
items.description: Software design principles for ML applications. Go from messy notebooks to maintainable, modular code with OOP essentials and refactoring guides.

items.name: fast.ai Practical Deep Learning
items.description: Train a model in 10 minutes. Understand why it works later. Jeremy Howard's famous 'code first, theory second' approach to deep learning.

items.name: Introduction to Statistical Learning
items.description: The 'I actually finished this one' ML book. Free with runnable Python code. Math when you need it, intuition first.

items.name: The Elements of Statistical Learning
items.description: The more rigorous sibling of ISLR. Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman's classic on statistical learning theory. Free PDF from Stanford.

items.name: Forecasting: Principles and Practice
items.description: Rob Hyndman's free book on time series forecasting. ARIMA, ETS, hierarchical forecasting — with R code.

items.name: Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction

items.name: NABE applied analytics Conference
items.description: NABE's conference for applied researchers. Covers causal inference, AI, and experiments in action. Practitioners from major tech companies share insights.

items.name: NBER Summer Institute: Digital Economics
items.description: NBER session on Digital Economics and AI. Research on digital surveillance, AI labor effects, and human-AI collaboration. Top academic researchers.

items.name: Northwestern Antitrust Conference
items.description: Annual conference on antitrust economics and competition policy. Covers digital acquisitions, buyer/seller power, and exclusive dealing research.

items.name: Stanford SITE
items.description: Stanford Institute for Theoretical Economics summer sessions. Includes Empirical Market Design and Market Failures tracks relevant to applied researchers.

items.name: Stigler Center Antitrust Conference
items.description: Chicago Booth conference on economic concentration and competition. Covers digital platforms, media markets, and antitrust policy.

items.name: The Web Conference (WWW)
items.description: Premier conference on understanding the Web through computer science, economics, and policy. Features dedicated economics and e-commerce research tracks.

items.name: WINE
items.description: Conference on Web and Internet Economics. Focuses on game theory, mechanism design, and economic aspects of internet and web systems.

items.name: DataTalks.Club
items.description: Large Slack community (74,000+ members) for data scientists, ML engineers, and analysts. Free courses, weekly events, and active discussions on ML and data engineering.

items.name: dbt Community
items.description: Slack community (66,000+ members) for analytics engineers. Discussions on data transformation, SQL best practices, and modern data stack. Global meetup groups.

items.name: Economics Discord
items.description: Discord community (3,500+ members) run by economics professors and practitioners. Discussions on economic research, econometrics, and policy.

items.name: Locally Optimistic
items.description: Slack community (8,000+ members) for analytics leaders. Exchange experiences and advice on building data teams, analytics strategy, and career growth.

items.name: Data Science Learning Community
items.description: Slack community for data science learners. Weekly book clubs, TidyTuesday projects, and peer support for R, Python, and statistics.

items.name: Academic Economics Discord
items.description: Discord server (8,400+ members) for discussing econ grad school paths, life in PhD programs, and academic economics careers.

items.name: Matteo Courthoud
items.description: Zalando Applied Scientist. Weekly posts on causal inference with code — CUPED, causal forests, AIPW, and more.

items.name: Apoorva Lal
items.description: Amazon/Netflix researcher. Causal inference notes, pyfixest maintainer, clean Python implementations of econometric methods.

items.name: Nick Huntington-Klein
items.description: 'The Effect' author. Animated causal inference plots, Library of Statistical Techniques founder.

items.name: Scott Cunningham
items.description: 'Causal Inference: The Mixtape' author. Substack on causal inference, Mixtape Sessions workshops.

items.name: Andrew Gelman
items.description: Columbia statistician. 20 years of blogging on Bayesian stats, causal inference, and social science methodology.

items.name: James Brand
items.description: Microsoft researcher. Demand estimation, cloud pricing, Julia packages for IO.

items.name: Eugene Yan
items.description: Principal Applied Scientist at Amazon. RecSys, LLMs, and ML systems. Author of applied-llms.org and applyingml.com. Prolific writer on building ML products at scale.

items.name: Paul Goldsmith-Pinkham
items.description: Yale researcher. 'A Causal Affair' substack with Reader's Digest breakdowns of Econometrica papers. Accessible yet rigorous causal inference.

items.name: Sean J. Taylor
items.description: Ex-Lyft/Facebook DS lead. Co-creator of Prophet. Writes on causal inference in tech, experimentation, and 'when do we actually need causal inference?'

items.name: Francis DiTraglia
items.description: Oxford econometrician. Frank, educational posts on statistical pitfalls, instrumental variables, and how to read econometrics papers.

items.name: Andrew Heiss
items.description: Master of R/Tidyverse explainers. Demystifying series on ATE vs ATT, DAGs, Bayesian priors. Clear code examples for causal inference.

items.name: David McKenzie
items.description: World Bank researcher. Legendary methodology posts on randomization, power calculations, and missing data — directly applicable to A/B testing.

items.name: Marc Bellemare
items.description: 'Metrics Monday archive. Applied econometrics advice on standard errors, weak instruments, and practical research design.

items.name: Matheus Facure
items.description: 'Causal Inference for the Brave and True' author. The primary bridge between econometric theory and Python production code. DML, uplift modeling, and synthetic controls implemented.

items.name: Aleksander Molak
items.description: Causal Discovery specialist. When you need to discover the causal graph from data (not assume it). DoWhy, CausalPy, and Bayesian networks.

items.name: Juan Camilo Orduz
items.description: Applied Scientist. Bayesian stats, PyMC, and geo-experimentation. Solves business problems (marketing attribution, geo-lift) with heavy-duty Bayesian math.

items.name: Alex Deng
items.description: Co-author 'Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments'. Deep A/B testing statistics — variance reduction, sequential testing, stopping rules without p-hacking.

items.name: Christoph Molnar
items.description: 'Interpretable Machine Learning' author. Opens black-box models to understand feature importance (Shapley values) — the ML equivalent of regression coefficients.

items.name: Nathan Lambert
items.description: Interconnects. The primary chronicler of RLHF. RLHF as mechanism design for AI: eliciting preferences and training reward models.

items.name: Andrej Karpathy
items.description: Neural nets from scratch, LLMs as operating systems. Explains the intuition of optimization landscapes, not just how to write code.

items.name: Lilian Weng
items.description: Lil'Log. OpenAI Safety Systems lead. The single best technical summaries on DL, agents, and RL. Often cited as primary sources in papers.

items.name: Sebastian Raschka
items.description: Ahead of AI. PyTorch, LLM training, efficient finetuning (LoRA). Bridges academic papers and 'will this run on my GPU?' practicality.

items.name: Tor Lattimore
items.description: DeepMind. The definitive resource on bandit algorithms. Essential for pricing, dynamic allocation, and experimentation.

items.name: Pranjal Rawat
items.description: applied researcher. Posts on applied research, causal inference, and data science in industry.

items.name: Microsoft Research ALICE (EconML/DoWhy)
items.description: Most widely-adopted causal ML tools. EconML for heterogeneous treatment effects, DoWhy for causal inference. Key researchers: Vasilis Syrgkanis, Amit Sharma.

items.name: Uber CausalML
items.description: Industry standard for uplift modeling and CATE estimation. Meta-learners (S, T, X, R). Key researchers: Huigang Chen, Totte Harinen.

items.name: Google Market Algorithms
items.description: Auction design, mechanism design, autobidding systems. Led by Vahab Mirrokni. Shapes Google's advertising marketplace.

items.name: Meta Core Data Science
items.description: Experimentation at scale, network effects, peer effects, advertising analytics. Led by Nicolas Stier-Moses (VP).

items.name: Netflix Causal Inference
items.description: Causal inference for recommender systems. CompCI project, annual CIDER roundtable. Research advisor: Nathan Kallus (Cornell).

items.name: Spotify Causal Inference Lab
items.description: Synthetic control, long-term causal effects. Published in Nature Machine Intelligence (2023). Led by Ciarán Gilligan-Lee.

items.name: Amazon Science Economics
items.description: Pricing Labs for A/B testing price changes, switchback experiments, marketplace analytics at scale.

items.name: LinkedIn Economic Graph
items.description: Labor market analysis using LinkedIn's professional network data. Skills taxonomy, workforce trends.

items.name: Salesforce AI Economist
items.description: Open-source framework for economic policy simulation using reinforcement learning. Multi-agent economic environments.

items.name: Stanford Golub Capital Social Impact Lab (GRF)
items.description: Created Generalized Random Forests (grf R package). Susan Athey, Stefan Wager, Guido Imbens (Nobel). The gold standard for causal forests.

items.name: MIT Economics & Data Science
items.description: Costis Daskalakis (mechanism design), Parag Pathak (school choice, NBER Market Design), Nikhil Agarwal (empirical market design).

items.name: Harvard EconCS Group
items.description: Mechanism design, computational social choice, AI for markets. David Parkes, Milind Tambe, Yiling Chen. GemNet won EC'24 Exemplary Paper.

items.name: UC Berkeley Simons Institute
items.description: World's premier collaborative programs in theoretical CS and economics. Semester programs on Economics and Computation.

items.name: Opportunity Insights
items.description: Raj Chetty's lab. Opportunity Atlas, Social Capital Atlas, Economic Tracker. Most widely-used public policy big data.

items.name: Learn Python
items.description: Programming fundamentals for researchers — data manipulation, visualization, and workflows

items.name: Learn Statistics
items.description: Hypothesis testing, inference, and distributions — the foundation for empirical work

items.name: Learn ML
items.description: Prediction, tree models, and cross-validation — for forecasting and pattern recognition

items.name: Learn Causal Inference
items.description: Treatment effects, DiD, RDD, and IV — answer 'what if' questions with data

items.name: Learn Product Sense
items.description: Metrics, experimentation, and business thinking — bridge economics and product decisions

items.name: Learn SQL
items.description: Querying data, joins, and aggregations — essential for any data role

items.name: Learn LeetCode
items.description: Data structures and algorithms for coding interviews — learn foundations first, then grind

items.name: Learn Automation
items.description: Web scraping, APIs, and workflow automation — collect and process data at scale

items.name: Learn Optimization (OR)
items.description: Linear programming, convex optimization, and combinatorial methods — solve pricing, scheduling, and allocation problems

items.name: Learn Agentic Workflows
items.description: Build AI agents that reason, plan, and execute — tool use, multi-agent systems, and orchestration

items.name: Information Rules
items.description: The foundational text on network economics - Varian became Google's Chief Economist

items.name: Matchmakers
items.description: Rigorous platform economics by two top IO economists

items.name: Platform Revolution
items.description: Most comprehensive platform strategy book

items.name: Who Gets What—and Why
items.description: Market design from a Nobel laureate - auctions, matching markets

items.name: Prediction Machines
items.description: Best economic framework for AI as cheap prediction

items.name: Power and Prediction
items.description: AI's system-level disruption - sequel to Prediction Machines

items.name: The Attention Merchants
items.description: History and economics of attention and advertising

items.name: Subprime Attention Crisis
items.description: Adtech's inflated metrics - essential for advertising economists

items.name: Priceless
items.description: Pricing psychology and behavioral economics

items.name: Confessions of the Pricing Man
items.description: Practitioner pricing strategy from the world's leading pricing consultant

items.name: The Age of Surveillance Capitalism
items.description: Data economics and behavioral surplus extraction

items.name: Weapons of Math Destruction
items.description: Algorithmic bias and fairness - ML economics

items.name: The Alignment Problem
items.description: AI alignment with human values - relevant to responsible AI

items.name: The Curse of Bigness
items.description: Concise antitrust primer for tech

items.name: The Great Reversal
items.description: Data-driven competition economics

items.name: The Platform Delusion
items.description: Contrarian take - when network effects don't matter

items.name: Radical Markets
items.description: Mechanism design ideas - auctions, Harberger taxes, quadratic voting

items.name: Uberland
items.description: Algorithmic management and gig economy

items.name: The Filter Bubble
items.description: Personalization and recommendation economics

items.name: Invisible Engines
items.description: Early platform economics - software as two-sided markets
